content: Transform this into a web-based USMLE Step 1 study companion called AorteQ with these essential baseline features:  Authentication System: A. Welcome/Login Page:  Clean centered layout with AorteQ logo at top  "Login with your Aorteq account " header text Email input field with validation Password input field with show/hide toggle  "Forgot Password? " link (light purple, right-aligned) Primary  "Login " button (filled purple) Divider with  "Or " text  "Sign in with Google " button (white with Google logo)  "Sign in with Apple " button (black with Apple logo)  "Don't have account? Create an Account " text link at bottom All form fields should have proper validation and error states   Initial Study Plan Setup: A. Three-Step Wizard Interface:  Progress indicator at top showing 3 steps Back and Continue buttons at bottom Each step on its own page with slide transitions  Step 1: Exam Selection & Date   "Let's tailor things to your study plan " header USMLE Step 1 selector dropdown Calendar date picker for exam date Info text explaining time calculation  Step 2: Topic Selection  Multi-select grid layout showing:  Basic Sciences section:  Behavioral Science Pharmacy Biochemist Lab Epidemiology Lab Microbiology Lab   Organ Systems section:  Cardio Clinic Endocrine Clinic MSK Clinic Neuro Clinic Respiratory Clinic     Checkboxes for each topic Search/filter option for topics  Step 3: Study Schedule  Hours per day input (default: 3hr 30min) Weekly schedule selector  7-day grid showing M-Su Ability to select study days Visual indication of selected days   Automatic calculation of study plan duration Warning if schedule needs adjustment   Question Bank (QBank) Interface: A. Question View:  Progress bar at top showing position (e.g.  "Question 10/15 ") Question number and text in main area Medical case presentation format Image display area when applicable (right side) Answer options (A-E) in vertical layout Each option clearly separated Hover and selected states for options  "Eliminate Answer " toggle button Previous/Next navigation buttons Timer display (optional)  B. Session Analysis Dashboard:  Large circular progress chart showing session score Key metrics displayed prominently:  Questions completed (e.g.  "45/50 ") Accuracy percentage (70%) Average time per question (1m 30s) Total session time (0h 32m)   Performance breakdown by system/topic Bar charts showing strength/weakness areas Detailed question list with:  Correct/incorrect indicators Time spent per question Topic categorization     Progress Tracking Dashboard: A. Main Overview:  User's name and exam countdown timer Large circular progress indicator showing overall completion Weekly progress bar chart Study streak counter with visual indicators Score prediction meter showing:  Current predicted score (e.g.  "221 ") Passing score line (196) Target score line (240+)   Recent assessment scores:  Test name (e.g.  "NBME 25 ") Score achieved Date taken Trend indicators   Weekly subject breakdown Performance metrics for each topic    All features should follow these technical requirements:  Responsive web design (minimum supported width: 1024px) Clean, medical-professional aesthetic Primary color: #6366F1 (purple) Consistent spacing system Clear typography hierarchy Loading states for all async operations Error handling with user feedback Session persistence Real-time progress saving Browser compatibility: Latest Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge  This baseline version focuses on the core study experience while maintaining a professional and user-friendly interface that can be expanded with additional features in future iterations.

content.overview: Transform the existing Flutter app into a web-based USMLE Step 1 study companion called AorteQ, focusing on implementing an authentication system, initial study plan setup, question bank interface, and progress tracking dashboard. This involves significant UI/UX updates, data model changes, and state management adjustments to support new features and ensure a responsive, professional design.
new_features: Authentication System with email/password and social login options
Three-step wizard for initial study plan setup
Question Bank interface with question view and session analysis dashboard
Progress Tracking Dashboard with user performance metrics
modified_features: Update existing UI components to match the new design aesthetic
Adjust state management to accommodate new features and data flows
Enhance routing to support new navigation paths
removed_features: Simple counter functionality as it is no longer relevant to the new application purpose
content.architectural_changes: Adopt a more modular architecture to support the new features, ensuring separation of concerns and scalability. Update the folder structure to include new components for authentication, study plan setup, question bank, and progress tracking. Consider using a state management solution like Provider or Riverpod for better scalability and maintainability.
cross_cutting_concerns: Implement comprehensive testing strategy including unit, integration, and UI tests
Update documentation to reflect new features and architectural changes
Optimize performance for web deployment, ensuring responsive design
Ensure security best practices are followed, especially for authentication and data handling

content:
# Summary of Changes

## Architectural Changes

The application has transitioned from a Stacked architecture to a modular architecture. This change enhances scalability and ensures separation of concerns by dedicating views and viewmodels to each feature. The features now include authentication, study plan setup, question bank, and progress tracking.

## Dependency Changes

The `gap` dependency, previously used for creating gaps in layouts, has been replaced with `provider` for state management. The version of the `provider` package has been updated from `^2.0.0` to `^5.0.0`. This change implies a shift in the state management strategy, which now uses a scalable solution like Provider or Riverpod.

## File Structure and Component Changes

The file structure has been reorganized to align with the new modular architecture. The application now includes separate folders for each feature (authentication, study plan, question bank, progress tracking) instead of the previous structure (app setup, features, UI components, utilities).

The `AppView` and `StartupView` have been replaced with `LoginView`, `StudyPlanView`, `QuestionView`, and `ProgressView`. These changes reflect the new features introduced in the application.

The corresponding ViewModel files have also been added for each view, managing the business logic and state for their respective views.

## Method Changes

Several methods have been added, removed, or modified across different files. Notably, the `login` method in `login_viewmodel.dart` and the `setupStudyPlan` method in `study_plan_viewmodel.dart` have been added. These methods handle user login logic and study plan setup, respectively.

## Navigation Flow Changes

The navigation flow has been updated to start with `LoginView` and proceed to `StudyPlanView`, `QuestionView`, and finally `ProgressView` upon successful authentication, study plan setup, and question answering.

## Package Name Change

The package name has been updated from `com.com.walturn.gyde_app` to `com.com.walturn.aorteq_app`.

## Project Description Update

The project description has been updated to reflect the new features and focus of the application. The application is now described as a web-based USMLE Step 1 study companion called AorteQ, featuring an authentication system, initial study plan setup, question bank interface, and progress tracking dashboard.

## Sequence Diagram Update

The sequence diagram has been updated to reflect the new navigation flow and interactions between the user and the application's views and viewmodels.

## State Management Flow Update

The state management flow has been updated to reflect the use of Provider or Riverpod for state management. The ViewModels now handle the business logic and state for their respective views, ensuring separation of concerns and maintainability.

## Action Items

Developers should familiarize themselves with the new modular architecture and the Provider or Riverpod state management solutions. They should update their local environments to include the new `provider` dependency and remove the deprecated `gap` dependency. They should also adjust their code to align with the new file structure and component changes, and update their navigation logic to align with the new navigation flow.
